Graphical abstract Due to the development of material synthesis and characterization technology, as well as limited computational resources, the understanding of CO activation on Fe-based Fischer − Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts is still changing, making catalyst screening and rational design difficult. In this work, we propose a novel model that bridges the structure of common iron carbides (including o-Fe7C3, χ-Fe5C2, θ-Fe3C, η-Fe2C and ε-Fe2.2C) with their CO activation capability. Using spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT), we explored CO activation pathways on a series of defective o-Fe7C3 surfaces. Advanced machine learning (ML) algorithms suitable for small datasets were employed to construct descriptor formulism with high predictive power for CO dissociation barriers. The ML-derived descriptor formulism unifies the catalytic expressions of various iron carbide phases, emphasizing the crucial roles of work function, carbon-vacancy formation energy, CO adsorption energy, coordination number, and the size of reaction sites in the CO dissociation process. This approach provides a deeper understanding of catalytic performance of distinct iron carbide surfaces and is applicable for designing high-performance catalysts for FTS, thereby accelerating catalyst development. Furthermore, the strategy for identifying descriptors with a limited dataset highlights the potential of combining DFT and ML methods. Keywords Fischer−Tropsch synthesis Iron carbides CO activation DFT calculation Machine learning Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Confronted with the challenges of resource depletion and the goal of achieving carbon neutrality, there is a growing search for the utilization of coal, natural gas, and biomass for the clean and efficient transformation of carbon resources. [1–4] Fischer − Tropsch synthesis (FTS), as a key technology for energy utilization, can convert coal- and biomass- based syngas (CO/H2) into fuels as well as various high-value chemicals, such as α-olefins and aromatics. [5,6] An excellent FTS catalyst must have an exceptional ability to activate CO, making the CO activation barrier a crucial parameter in evaluating catalyst performance. [7,8] Even if the CO dissociation step may not be the rate-limiting due to a low energy barrier, the initial step to activate the entire F-T process is still essential. Iron-based catalysts, with iron carbides (FeCx, e.g. Fe7C3, Fe5C2, Fe3C, Fe2C and Fe2.2C) as the active phases, have been widely applied in FTS, due to their low cost, high activity and tolerance to poisons. [9] However, the phase behavior of FeCx is complex, with contentious findings regarding active phases from experimental perspectives [10,11]. For instance, while ε-Fe2(.2) C or χ-Fe5C2 exhibits notable activity at moderate temperatures (∼540 K) [12–15], Chang et al. [16] observed that Fe7C3 displays intrinsic activity at 533–573 K, which is three times higher than χ-Fe5C2. The development of computational chemistry has made it possible to elucidate the influence of crystal facets on FTS in greater detail. For example, Song et al. [17] recently found that η-Fe2C (121) surface has the lowest CO activation barrier, whereas Zhang et al. [18] reported that CO adsorption on the η-Fe2C (001) surface is favorable. Additionally, although the (510) surface is considered as the highly active facet of χ-Fe5C2, different structural and electronical parameters have been proposed to describe CO activation behavior [19,20]. Recently, Zeng et al. [21] found that the (202) facet of χ-Fe5C2 exhibits higher FTS activity compared to the (112) facet, due to a different CO dissociation mechanism observed in their experiments. Therefore, establishing a relationship between the surface structure characteristics of iron carbides and CO dissociation will inspire us to design and regulate F-T catalysts more purposefully. In earlier studies, CO activation was only considered to occur at Fe sites on FeCx. This perspective shifted in 2009 when Niemantsverdriet [22] proposed that CO tends to dissociate at carbon vacancies in carbon-saturated iron carbides, rather than on iron sites, following a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. This hypothesis has been validated by isotope tracing studies and in-situ spectroscopic characterization, confirming that surface carbon itself can participate as a carbon source in FTS. [23–25] Subsequent studies compared the barriers for CO dissociation on iron sites and carbon vacancies, consistently showing significantly lower barriers at carbon vacancies. [7,22,26–31]. However, even though it is confirmed that carbon vacancies serve as the dissociation sites for CO, it remains unclear why CO activation ability differs significantly among different carbon defective crystal facets. For example, a surface of iron-terminated carbide with more carbon vacancies does not necessarily enhance CO activation compared to other facets, as observed by Liu et al. [26] Instead, they found that CO activation is more likely occur on surfaces with a Fe-C mixture. Wen et al. [7,32] proposed that carbon atoms with lower coordination numbers are more active, implying that CO activation behavior on FeCx surfaces is facet-dependent. However, these qualitative observations do not apply to all cases, indicating the need for further exploration of the relationship between FeCx facet structures and CO activation barriers to establish a quantitative correlation. In other words, it is crucial to establish a structure–activity relationship between the surface properties of FeCx and its CO activation capability. Deep experimental characterization of catalysts requires significant resources and may encounter limitations, leading to difficulties in obtaining the desired information. Taking advantage of density functional theory (DFT), which does not rely on extensive experimental conditions to provide atomic structural information, researchers have identified numerous descriptors to elucidate the structure-performance relationship of iron carbides. Wen et al. [25] found a linear relationship between the energy barrier for the direct dissociation of CO and the CO bond valence (SBVCO). Chen et al. [20] discovered a linear relationship between the Fe atom charge and the activation barrier for CO. Song et al. [33] suggested that the wider the spatial configuration of the active site, the lower the CO activation barrier. Nørskov et al. [34] proposed that the reaction energy can serve as a descriptor for the activity of CO activation reactions. Although these descriptors can correlate a specific property of iron carbides surfaces with their CO activation ability, they do not adequately account for the varied catalytic behaviors of CO dissociation on surfaces with varying iron-to-carbon ratios. In other words, it is challenging to establish unified descriptors for different crystal facets with varying iron-to-carbon ratios, and even within the same iron-to-carbon ratio, due to the complexity of catalytic performance. For instance, the present descriptors cannot efficiently predict the CO activation barrier of a given iron carbide crystal facet. To overcome these limitations, utilizing ML to evaluate multiple suitable descriptors and establish a structure–activity relationship for iron-based catalysts has become a more advantageous strategy. However, there remains a notable absence of research employing ML techniques to explore the structure–activity relationship of CO activation in FTS. Our study aims to bridge this gap by introducing an approach that utilizes ML techniques to understand and predict the behavior of catalysts during the activation of CO. In this work, we employed ML techniques to establish the structure–activity relationship of CO activation in FTS process. Fe7C3 has been identified as the primary active phase after prolonged and high-temperature FTS by Brent Williams et al. and Li et al [16,35]. Fe7C3 presents two basic crystal structures: an orthorhombic form (o-Fe7C3) [36] and a hexagonal form (h-Fe7C3) [37]. Recent studies have shown that the orthorhombic structure is more stable than the hexagonal [26,38]. Although experimental evidence confirms the superior Fischer–Tropsch performance of Fe7C3 at high temperatures, [16] there is a scarcity of theoretical studies on this material. To address this, our investigation begins with the orthorhombic form of Fe7C3, aiming to understand how its surface structure influences the activation of CO. We performed DFT calculations to investigate the potential pathways for CO dissociation on various o-Fe7C3 surfaces. Subsequently, we established a correlation between the surface properties of o-Fe7C3 and the barriers for CO dissociation using Sufficient Input Subset Selection and Optimization (SISSO) [39], which is particularly well-suited for systems with limited data. Furthermore, the descriptor system developed through ML is applicable to the prediction of CO activation capabilities across a range of common iron carbides. The primary advantage of this model lies in its ability to avoid time-intensive DFT calculations typically required for searching transition states in traditional reaction path analyses. While some metrics used in our model, such as adsorption energies, do involve DFT calculations, their computational cost is significantly lower compared to the substantial resources needed for transition state searches. Furthermore, the proposed model can be applied to a wide range of iron carbide surfaces, making it an effective tool for screening and predicting CO activation across diverse systems. Therefore, the computational cost savings achieved during catalyst screening far outweigh the initial cost of building the dataset. This approach not only deepens our understanding of catalyst performance but also accelerates the identification of promising iron carbide surfaces. Ultimately, our work contributes to the development of more efficient catalysts for the FTS process. 2 Computational details 2.1 Methods In this study, all of the periodic spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP). [40–43] The plane-wave based spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [44,45] functional and projector augmented wave (PAW) [46] method. A plane wave cutoff of 400 eV and the spin polarization were used in the calculations. The Brillouin zone was sampled using a Monkhorst-Pack grid [47], with details provided in Table S1. Electronic occupancies were determined using the Methfessel-Paxton scheme [48] with an energy smearing of 0.2 eV. The geometry optimization would be converged when the energy difference was smaller than 1 × 10−5 eV, and the forces were less than 0.03 eV/Å. For evaluating the energy barriers, the transition states were determined by the climbing-image nudged elastic band method (CI-NEB) [49,50] and DIMER [51]. The frequency analysis was performed to confirm the located TS for the elementary reaction with only one imaginary frequency and zero-point energy (ZPE) was considered for all the calculated energy data. The adsorption energy of these species was defined as: Eads = E(adsorbate/slab) − [E(slab) + E(adsorbate)], where E(adsorbate/slab) is the total energy for the slabs with adsorbate on the surface, E(slab) is the total energy of the slab, and E(adsorbate) is the total energies of free surface adsorbate. The reaction energy and the barrier energy were calculated by ΔEr = E(FS)- E(IS) and Ea = E(TS) − E(IS), respectively, where E(IS), E(FS), and E(TS) are the energies of the corresponding initial state (IS), final state (FS), and transition state (TS), respectively. The surface energy was computed as: γ = 1/2(Esurf – Natoms ⋅ Ebulk) + Erel, where Esurf, Natoms, Ebulk, and Erel are the energy of fresh slab, the number of atoms in slab, the energy of a single atom in the bulk structure, and the relaxation energy, respectively. 2.2 Models o-Fe7C3 is an orthorhombic unit cell, optimized with a 5 × 3 × 2 Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh. The optimized unit cell parameters (a = 4.517 Å; b = 6.857 Å; c = 11.762 Å; β = 90°) agree with the experimental values [52]. In all calculations, half of atomic layers were fixed, while the other half and the adsorbates were allowed to relax. The top and side views of o-Fe7C3 are illustrated in Fig. 1 and Fig. S1, and detailed information of other surface models is listed in Table S1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Surfaces selection According to the reference XRD pattern (JCPDS 75–1499), the crystal facets with relatively intense diffraction peak are all high Miller index facets, such as (006), (024), (026), (033), (105), (124), (125), (132), (133), (134), (211), (222), and (237). However, previous studies on o-Fe7C3 [52–54] have focused on low Miller index facets, which are generally more stable. Therefore, in our study, we selected 13 high Miller index surfaces, including (006), (024), (026), (033), (105), (124), (125), (132), (133), (134), (211), (222), and (237), and 7 low Miller index surfaces, including (111), (110), (101), (100), (011), (010), and (001). Additionally, three criteria were used for surface selection: (i) Fe-C mixed surfaces, where CO activation occurs [26]; (ii) symmetrical surfaces for computational convenience; and (iii) stable surfaces. The surface energies of selected surfaces, ranging mainly from 2.4 to 3.4 eV (in Table 1 ), are consistent with the range of 2.2 to 3.1 eV reported by Chun and Kim [53]. It is evident that the surface energies of all high Miller index facets, except for (211), are higher than those of low Miller index counterparts, indicating their instability. Consequently, the high Miller index facets, except for (211) were eliminated from further consideration. Besides, we calculated the Wulff construction of o-Fe7C3, as shown in Fig. S2 and Table S3, and the results are consistent with our above analysis. Therefore, in the following sections, we focus on (001), (010), (011), (100), (101), (110), (111), and (211) surfaces. 3.2 H2 and CO adsorption The H2 desorption on the o-Fe7C3 surface is either an exothermic or endothermic process, depending on the surface properties. [26] The adsorption sites of H atoms can be roughly classified into two categories: adsorption on Fe sites (typically including top, bridge, and 3-fold hollow sites) and bonding with surface C to form CH. Since the adsorption of H atoms plays a crucial role in the FTS process, we initially screened various active sites on the o-Fe7C3 surface based on H adsorption. From the Table S4, it can be seen that, except for the (010) surface, H is exothermically adsorbed on surface C and Fe sites, particularly at 3-fold hollow and bridge sites. Therefore, the (010) surface was eliminated. Additionally, the adsorption energies of CO and the co-adsorption of CO and H were also calculated and listed in Table S5-12. The CO adsorption energies range from −1.90 to −2.54 eV, which are lower than those reported for adsorption on Fe sites (around −2.0 eV) [7,17,20,25]. This suggests that the presence of C-vacancies enhances the stable adsorption of CO, which is consistent with the findings of Jiao and Wen et al [7,29]. 3.3 CO activation The previous studies indicate that CO is preferentially activated at C-vacancies instead of Fe sites [7,22,26–31]. The C-vacancies tend to be filled with C atoms through surface reconstruction, which facilitates surface carbon hydrogenation reactions during the FTS process. Additionally, the desorption process creates C-vacancies, enabling a cycle of C-vacancy replenishment [26,31]. Therefore, we considered the formation of C-vacancies arising from CO dissociation. To rationalize the C-vacancy formation, we evaluated the formation energies (ECv ) on various surfaces, as shown in Table 2 . Liu et al. [26] found that carbon vacancies on surfaces are dynamically generated during the reaction process and are unlikely to persist in a vacant state. Therefore, we exclude three vacancies with negative ECv from further consideration, in line with realistic reaction conditions. Consequently, fourteen C-defective surfaces were selected for further investigation, including (211) Cv1-3, (111) Cv1-4, (110) Cv1-2, (101) Cv, (100) Cv1-2, (011) Cv and (001) Cv. We then conducted a systematic study of CO activation with and without H-assistance on the fourteen selected o-Fe7C3 surfaces. All identified transition states, along with the corresponding reaction energies and activation barriers, are summarized in Table S5-12. It is observed that the dissociation pathways of CO can vary depending on the adsorption configuration on the same site. For example, on the (211) Cv1 surface, when CO is adsorbed in a lying-down configuration, direct CO dissociation occurs with an energy barrier of 0.85 eV. However, when CO adopts a standing-up configuration, H-assisted CO dissociation is favored, with a lower energy barrier of 0.71 eV. This demonstrates the significant impact of adsorption on the dissociation process. Additionally, the most favorable reaction pathway for CO dissociation on each surface and the corresponding energies are listed in Table S13. The CO activation barriers, ranging from 0.53 to 1.29 eV, are lower than those on Fe sites [7,17,20,25] and comparable to those on C-vacancies [7,17,29], indicating that C-vacancies facilitate CO activation. Regarding direct CO dissociation, the (111) Cv4 surface exhibits the lowest dissociation barrier (0.53 eV). In contrast, for H-assisted dissociation, the (101) Cv surface shows the lowest dissociation barrier (0.55 eV). Furthermore, both carbon vacancies on the (100) surface display higher CO dissociation barriers compared to other surfaces. We also evaluated alternative intermediates in H-assisted dissociation, such as CH2O* and HCOH*, but found their pathways to be energetically unfavorable. Notably, both direct CO dissociation and H-assisted dissociation pathways were considered in the subsequent SISSO calculations due to their importance in the dissociation reaction mechanism. 3.4 Feature selection In order to establish the relationship between surface structures of o-Fe7C3 and activation barriers for CO dissociation, we calculated ten geometric and electronic features of o-Fe7C3 surfaces based on previous literature [26,33,34,55–62]. These features include the d-band center (εd ), work function (Φ), Fermi softness (SF ), Bader charge (Q), C-vacancy formation energy (ECv ), CO adsorption energy (Eads ), surface energy (γ), magnetic moment (μ), coordination numbers (CN) and the average distance of reaction site atoms from the center(r), with the results shown in Table S14. Among these features, some are expected to strongly correlate with the performance of o-Fe7C3 [20,33]. However, the correlations between these features and CO activation barriers do not follow a linear relationship (see Fig. S3). To identify the descriptors that are well correlated with CO activation barriers, we employed the SISSO algorithm to formulate an interpretable mathematic model for predicting the target property (CO activation barriers) based on the selected key features. To eliminate redundant primary features before SISSO training, a bivariate correlation matrix was employed to filter out the strongly correlated descriptors with an absolute value of the Pearson coefficient above 0.9. According to Fig. 2 a, the absolute values of correlation coefficients between descriptors (from 0.01 to 0.72) were found to be less than 0.9. Thus, further backward feature selection [63] was performed on the original feature set, as shown in Fig. 2b. As the original set contains 10 features, we started to construct 10 subsets comprising 9 features, and compared their individual fitting errors. The optimal subset was identified with the smallest error among the 10 subsets. Subsequently, the 10 subsets were reduced to 9 subsets with 8 features and through the fitting the optimal subset was obtained. The iteration process continued until the error reached a minimum, thereby the corresponding subset was considered the optimal feature set. Through backward feature selection, the optimal feature set was reduced from 10 elements to 5 which are CN, r, ECv , Eads , and Φ. 3.5 Model training and evaluation The complexity of the model is determined by two parameters: the number of descriptors (D) and the maximum number of mathematical operations allowed on the descriptors (O). SISSO model complexities vary from 1D1O to 5D5O, with performance evaluated by correlation coefficient (R2) and root mean square error (RMSE) (Fig. 3 a, 3b). Under the condition of R2 > 0.95, four models were selected: 4D4O, 4D5O, 5D4O, and 5D5O (Fig. 4 ). It is known that the accuracy of the trained models is generally improved with the increasing complexity. To avoid overfitting highly complex models, four sets of models with high accuracy were further screened through Leave-One-Out-Cross-Validation (LOOCV) [22] balancing accuracy and simplicity. In the cross-validation, each model was trained based on the data from 13 surfaces and validated using the masked data from the 14th. Therefore, the transferability of each trained model was evaluated using masked data from a surface that was completely different from the composition of the training set. The cross-validation results are shown in Fig. 4a. The error values indicate that the model with D = 4 and O = 4 is best suited to avoid overfitting. The optimal model being 4D4O with the smallest errors stands out from 14 models. As depicted in Fig. 4b, the model trained without data from the (111) Cv2 surface has the lowest error, which is described by the formula in equation (1): (1) y = c 1 Φ + E cv × r × E ads CN + c 2 r Φ + E Cv + 2 E ads + c 3 r 3 + c 4 Φ E Cv Φ + 2 E ads + c 0 where c0-c4 are constants, with values of 3.63, 1.02, 7.91 × 10-3, −1.25 × 10-1, and 6.33 × 10-4, respectively. R2 and RMSE for equation (1) are shown in Fig. 4c. 3.6 Descriptor sensitivity analysis and physical interpretation To gain an intuitive understanding of the impact of each feature in the ML predicted model, a sensitivity analysis of equation (1) was performed using the perturbation method [64]. This method involves tuning the value of a specific fundamental feature while holding the rest features constant. The sensitivity coefficient is given by (2) NS C i M = 1 m ∑ j = 1 m ∂ E aj ∂ z j i · max z i - max z i max E a - max E a where zij represents the input feature i of the sample j. Eaj is the CO dissociation barrier of sample j, and m is the number of samples in the dataset. To facilitate direct comparison among inputs, an additional scaling factor is applied in equation (2). This scaling normalizes the output and accounts for the different scales of input features. Accordingly, the more significant changes in the CO activation energy correspond to the larger absolute values of the sensitivity coefficient, provided that the features are scaled by the same factor. The sensitivities of Ea on different surfaces of o-Fe7C3 under the fundamental features are illustrated in Fig. 5 . It is found that, (i) ECv is a dominant feature in CO dissociation, with a sensitivity coefficient of 1.86, which aligns with the essential role of the C vacancy in CO dissociation; (ii) r, representing the size of the active site, has a secondary impact on CO dissociation, highlighting the significance of an appropriate reaction space; (iii) the sensitivity to Eads and Φ for CO dissociation is similar, with sensitivity coefficients of 0.67 and 0.64, respectively; (iv) CN has the smallest impact on CO dissociation, with a sensitivity coefficient of 0.39. The purpose of sensitivity analysis is to elucidate the impact of predicted values on fundamental features. However, evaluating the local impact of individual features by holding others constant provides a partial view of the whole landscape of CO dissociation barriers. Since SISSO itself is a descriptor-based ML method that offers explicit expression related to features, we further analyze the descriptor formula consisting of the basic features. The relative contributions of each term from left to right on the right-hand side of equation (1), excluding the constant term (c0), are as follows: 61 %, 5 %, 33 %, and 2 %, respectively. The first term including all features, highlights the essential role of each feature in predicting CO activation barriers. The third term, predominantly influenced by active site size (r), ranks second in contribution, indicating that CO activation barriers are sensitive to the active site size. The remaining two terms contribute less, indicating their presence in subtle tuning correlations. Analyzing the model in conjunction with the ranges of features reveals that a larger reaction site and a smaller CN are associated with lower Ea , which is consistent with previous research results. [32,33] Notably, there is no straightforward monotonic relationship between Ea and the individual features such as ECv , Eads , and Φ. This suggests that C-vacancies should be neither easily formed, which could destabilize CO adsorption, nor difficultly formed, resulting in insufficient CO activation sites. CO should neither be strongly adsorbed on C-vacancies, as this would hinder subsequent reactions, nor weakly adsorbed, as this would prevent the initiation of reactions. This observation is in line with previous research findings. [32] The work function of the catalyst surface should neither be too high nor too low, reflecting a necessary level of electron activity on the surface. By comparing the features of surfaces and the CO dissociation barriers, it can be observed that the CO activation ability of each facet can be plausibly interpreted by the aforementioned rules. For instance, although both (111) Cv4 and (111) Cv1 have high ECv and low Eads , the Ea for CO dissociation on (111) Cv4 is approximately half that of (111) Cv1. This discrepancy is attributed to the smaller r, which does not offer adequate space for CO dissociation, causing CO to adsorb in an upright position on the C-vacancy. In contrast, although (101) Cv also has a small r, its lower CN facilitates a horizontal adsorption configuration for CO on the C-vacancy. Moreover, the balanced values of ECv and Eads are neither too high nor too low, leading to the smaller Ea . Despite having the lowest CN, (100) Cv1 exhibits the highest Eads , resulting in the highest dissociation Ea . To understand the activation mechanism of CO on o-Fe7C3, the electron localization function (ELF) calculations were further performed (Fig. 6 ). As shown in Fig. 6a, the carbon atom in the CO molecule carries the positive charges while the oxygen atom carries the negative charges. Notably, the (111)Cv4 surface, which favors CO dissociation, features a reaction site with remarkably higher electron density distributions compared to other surfaces, as shown in Fig. 6b. Therefore, this surface is more effective at adsorbing CO and providing the electrons for CO dissociation. Φ, ECv , and Eads are key descriptors reflecting the electronic properties of FeCx surfaces. The iron atoms at the vacancies are coordinatively unsaturated, and thus, Φ primarily reflects the ease with which electrons are removed from the iron atoms at the vacancy sites. ECv describes how easily a surface carbon atom can depart from the surface, with electron transfer. Therefore, these two descriptors indicate the ability of the iron atoms in the vacancy to donate electrons. According to the Blyholder model [65], after CO adsorbs on a metal surface, CO donates electrons from its 5σ orbital to the metal d-band, while the d-band donates electrons to the 2π* orbital of CO. These interactions weaken the C-O bond. It is widely accepted that the electron filling of the 5σ orbital of CO remains nearly constant, so the electron donation from the metal d-band to the 2π* orbital of CO is the determining factor. Therefore, Φ and ECv reflect the capability of electron transfer between CO and iron. Recently, Hensen et al. [66] investigated CO activation on cobalt surfaces and found that the 1π orbital of CO also plays a role in CO activation, donating electrons to cobalt. Taking (111)Cv4 and (100)Cv1 as examples, these are the two sites with the lowest (−2.34 eV) and highest (−1.90 eV) Eads , respectively. A comparison of the projected density of states (PDOS) of these two surfaces shows that the overlap of the 1π orbital of CO with the iron d-band is weaker at (100)Cv1 than at (111)Cv4, indicating that the electron donation from CO to the iron is weaker (Fig. 7 ). Thus, Eads reflects the electron transfer between CO and iron. 3.7 Prediction for other facets To validate the transferability of ML model to surfaces with varying iron-carbon ratios, we selected eight surfaces from the existing literature [7,17,26,29,67,68]. We applied our developed model to predict the CO activation energies for these eight crystal facets and compared the results with the literature values. Among them, Fe5C2 (100) [7] was built by different level of carbon defect, therefore we calculate the DFT result of this surface instead of using the literature value (details are provided in Table S18). The feature values for the eight test surfaces are provided in Table S15. It is worth noting that, although the ECv for the χ-Fe5C2 (510) surface is low, the ML model still successfully predicts the CO activation energy. As shown in Table 3 , the relative errors of ML predictions compared to DFT results are generally below 15 %, except of Fe3C (100). After excluding the highest and lowest errors, the average relative error is 9.13 %, indicating the applicability of the ML model to a variety of iron carbide surfaces beyond o-Fe7C3. In order to demonstrate the applicability of our proposed model, we applied it to predict the CO activation behavior on Fe2.2C, which is suggested as a primary active phase. We calculated the surface energies of seven low Miller index facets of Fe2.2C, namely (001), (010), (011), (100), (101), (110), and (111), and selected two stable surfaces, (001) and (100), as shown in Table S16. Among them, the carbon vacancy formation energy on the (001) surface is relatively high (1.22 eV), leading to its exclusion. On the (100) surface, two distinct carbon vacancies were identified, and we predicted the CO activation energy barriers at these two vacancies to be 0.71 eV and 0.95 eV, respectively (Table S17). Therefore, the first carbon vacancy (with a lower activation barrier) was identified as a favorable site for CO activation. To validate our conclusion, we performed DFT calculations on the first site, which yielded an activation energy of 0.84 eV (Table S18). The relative error compared to the model prediction was 15.48 %, confirming that our model accurately predicted the CO dissociation active site on Fe2.2C. Overall, this method enables rapid screening of favorable active surfaces and corresponding active sites, providing valuable guidance for the design of iron-based catalysts in experimental studies. 4 Conclusions In this work, we utilized DFT calculations combined with SISSO-based machine learning to establish a correlation between the surface features of o-Fe7C3 and the activation barriers for CO activation in FTS. Given that Fe7C3 serves as the primary active phase in medium-to-high-temperature FTS, we focused our research on o-Fe7C3 to provide data on CO activation across various surfaces. To streamline our approach and avoid the complexities of time-consuming DFT calculations, we used computed DFT data on o-Fe7C3 to develop a predictive model that correlates catalyst structural features with CO dissociation capabilities. The machine learning model, derived from features such as work function, carbon-vacancy formation energy, CO adsorption energy, coordination number, and reaction site size, identifies key factors influencing CO dissociation. Importantly, this model demonstrates applicability beyond o-Fe7C3, extending to surfaces with varying iron-carbon ratios. In contrast to previous studies, we unified various iron carbide phases into a single model, employing five key features to assess CO activation across surfaces with different iron-carbon ratios under identical conditions. This approach not only deepens our understanding of catalyst performance but also speeds up the screening of potential iron carbide surfaces, leading to more effective catalyst design for FTS. coredata.dc:description: Due to the development of material synthesis and characterization technology, as well as limited computational resources, the understanding of CO activation on Fe-based Fischer − Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts is still changing, making catalyst screening and rational design difficult. In this work, we propose a novel model that bridges the structure of common iron carbides (including o-Fe7C3, χ-Fe5C2, θ-Fe3C, η-Fe2C and ε-Fe2.2C) with their CO activation capability. Using spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT), we explored CO activation pathways on a series of defective o-Fe7C3 surfaces. Advanced machine learning (ML) algorithms suitable for small datasets were employed to construct descriptor formulism with high predictive power for CO dissociation barriers. The ML-derived descriptor formulism unifies the catalytic expressions of various iron carbide phases, emphasizing the crucial roles of work function, carbon-vacancy formation energy, CO adsorption energy, coordination number, and the size of reaction sites in the CO dissociation process. This approach provides a deeper understanding of catalytic performance of distinct iron carbide surfaces and is applicable for designing high-performance catalysts for FTS, thereby accelerating catalyst development. Furthermore, the strategy for identifying descriptors with a limited dataset highlights the potential of combining DFT and ML methods.
